dialogs.original: Save thee, friend, and thy music. Dost thou live by thytabour?
dialogs.translated: God bless you, friend, and your music. Do you make your living by playing your drum?

dialogs.original: No, sir, I live by the church.
dialogs.translated: No, sir, I live by the church.

dialogs.original: Art thou a churchman?
dialogs.translated: Are you a clergyman?

dialogs.original: No such matter, sir. I do live by the church; for I dolive at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.
dialogs.translated: Not at all, sir. I live by the church because I live in my house, and my house is by the church.

dialogs.original: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggardwell near him,   or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
dialogs.translated: You may as well say then that the king sleeps with a beggar if a beggar lives near him, or that the church stands next to your drum if your drum stands next to the church.

dialogs.original: You have said, sir. To see this age!   A sentence is buta cheveril glove to a good wit. How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!
dialogs.translated: You're right, sir. What a wonder this modern age is! A sentence is like a supple glove for good witit can be turned inside out so quickly!

dialogs.original: Nay, thats certain. They that dally nicely with words may quickly make them wanton.
dialogs.translated: Yes, that's certainly true. Those who play around with words too much can quickly make them changeable and promiscuous.

dialogs.original: I would therefore my sister had no name, sir.
dialogs.translated: If that's so, then I wish my sister didn't have a name, sir.

dialogs.original: Why, man?
dialogs.translated: Why, man?

dialogs.original: Why, sir, her names a word, and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton.   But, indeed, words arevery rascals since bonds disgraced them.
dialogs.translated: Well, sir, her name's a word, and to play around with that word might make my sister promiscuous. But indeed, words have been rascals ever since people started needing written contracts to guarantee them.

dialogs.original: Thy reason, man?
dialogs.translated: What's your reason for that, man?

dialogs.original: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.
dialogs.translated: Truly, sir, I can't give you a reason without using words, and since words have become so false and unreliable, I'm hesitant to use them for my proof.

dialogs.original: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.
dialogs.translated: I'll bet you're a happy fellow, without a care in the world.

dialogs.original: Not so, sir, I do care for something. But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you.   If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
dialogs.translated: Not so, sir, I do care for something. But honestly, sir, I don't care for you. If that means that I care for nothing, sir, then you should become invisible right nowas you're nothing.

dialogs.original: Art not thou the Lady Olivias fool?
dialogs.translated: Aren't you the Lady Olivia's fool?

dialogs.original: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly. She willkeep no fool, sir, till she be married,   and fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings; the husbands the bigger:   I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter of words.
dialogs.translated: No indeed, sir, the Lady Olivia has no foolishness. She won't keep a fool until she gets married. Fools are to husbands as anchovies are to sardineshusbands are the larger version. I'm not her fool, just her corrupter of words.

dialogs.original: I saw thee late at the Count Orsinos.
dialogs.translated: I saw you at Duke Orsino's recently.

dialogs.original: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun. It shines everywhere.   I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: Ithink I saw your wisdom there.
dialogs.translated: Foolishness, sir, wanders about the earth like the sun. It's everywhere. I'd be sorry if your master was less acquainted with foolishness than my mistress is. I think I saw you there, you wise man.

dialogs.original: Nay, an thou pass upon me, Ill no more with thee. Hold, theres expenses for thee.
dialogs.translated: If you're just going to make fun of me, I want nothing to do with it. But wait, here's a coin for you.

dialogs.original: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
dialogs.translated: May God, in his next shipment of hair, send you a beard!

dialogs.original: By my troth, Ill tell thee, I am almost sick for one,  (aside]  though I would not have it grow on my chin.  [To fool]  Is thy lady within?
dialogs.translated: Honestly, I'm telling you, I'm dying for one, [To herself] though I don't want it on my own chinI'm dying for a certain man with a beard.

dialogs.original: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?
dialogs.translated: If I had a pair of these coins, sir, do you think they'd have children?

dialogs.original: Yes, being kept together and put to use.
dialogs.translated: Yes, if they were kept together and invested.

dialogs.original: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring aCressida to this Troilus.
dialogs.translated: I'd like to play the pimp, sir, and bring these two lovers together.

dialogs.original: [giving him money]  I understand you, sir. 'Tis well begged.
dialogs.translated: [Giving him money] I understand you sir. You're pretty good at begging.

dialogs.original: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar. Cressida was a beggar.   My lady is within, sir. Iwill construe to them whence you come.   Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say element, but the word is overworn.
dialogs.translated: It's no problem for me, sir, as I'm only begging on a beggar's behalf. The famous lover Cressida became a beggar in her old age, they say. My lady is inside, sir. I'll explain where you come from, but who you are and what you want are beyond my knowledge. I'd say I'm "not in my element," but those words are overused.

dialogs.original: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool,    And to do that well craves a kind of wit.    He must observe their mood on whom he jests,    The quality of persons, and the time,    And, like the haggard, check at every feather    That comes before his eye.   This is a practise    As full of labor as a wise mans art,    For folly that he wisely shows is fit.    But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.
dialogs.translated: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool, and to do that well you have to be clever. He has to pay attention to the mood and status of the person he's mocking, the time, and must also pursue every target he sees. This is a skill that requires just as much work as any wise man's job, for he plays the fool very wisely. Wise men, on the other hand, ruin their reputation for intelligence when they try to play the fool.

dialogs.original: Save you, gentleman.
dialogs.translated: God bless you, sir.

dialogs.original: And you, sir.
dialogs.translated: And you, sir.

dialogs.original: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.
dialogs.translated: [Speaking in French] May God protect you, sir.

dialogs.original: Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!
dialogs.translated: [Speaking in French] And you also. At your service!

dialogs.original: I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.
dialogs.translated: I hope so, sir, and I am at your service too.

dialogs.original: Will you encounter the house? My niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.
dialogs.translated: Will you come in the house? My niece wants you to, if your business is with her.

dialogs.original: I am bound to your niece, sir. I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
dialogs.translated: I'm bound for your niece, sir. I mean, she's the destination of my voyage.

dialogs.original: Taste your legs, sir. Put them to motion.
dialogs.translated: Try your legs then sir, and put them in motion.

dialogs.original: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understandwhat you mean by bidding me taste my legs.
dialogs.translated: My legs stand under me better than I understand you, and what you mean by "try your legs."

dialogs.original: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
dialogs.translated: I mean to enter the house, sir.

dialogs.original: I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we are prevented.
dialogs.translated: I'll answer you by walking in. But we've been anticipated.

dialogs.original: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!
dialogs.translated: Most excellent accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!

dialogs.original: (  aside  ) That youths a rare courtier. Rain odors. Well.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] That youth's a classy fellow. "Rain odors." Nice.

dialogs.original: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
dialogs.translated: My message can't be told to anyone, my lady. It's only for your own willing and receptive ears.

dialogs.original: [aside]  Odors, pregnant, and vouchsafed. Ill get'em all three all ready.
dialogs.translated: [To himself) "Odors," "willing," and "receptive." I'll have to remember those.

dialogs.original: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
dialogs.translated: Close the garden door and let me be alone to hear this message.

dialogs.original: Give me your hand, sir.
dialogs.translated: Give me your hand, sir.

dialogs.original: My duty, madam, and most humble service.
dialogs.translated: I offer you my obedience, madam, and my most humble service.

dialogs.original: What is your name?
dialogs.translated: What is your name?

dialogs.original: Cesario is your servants name, fair princess.
dialogs.translated: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

dialogs.original: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world    Since lowly feigning was calld compliment.    Youre servant to the Count Orsino, youth.
dialogs.translated: My servant, sir! The world has gone downhill since false humility started passing for a compliment. You're Duke Orsino's servant, youth, not mine.

dialogs.original: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:Your servants servant is your servant, madam.
dialogs.translated: But he is your servant, so all that he has is yours too. Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

dialogs.original: For him, I think not on him. For his thoughts,Would they were blanks, rather than filld with me.
dialogs.translated: As for him, I don't think about him. And as for his thoughts, I wish that they were blank pages instead of filled with pictures of me.

dialogs.original: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughtsOn his behalf.
dialogs.translated: Madam, I've come on his behalf to improve your feelings towards him.

dialogs.original: O, by your leave, I pray you,    I bade you never speak again of him.    But, would you undertake another suit,    I had rather hear you to solicit that    Than music from the spheres.
dialogs.translated: Oh, please, I beg you, I asked you never speak of him again. But if you would tell me that another man loves me instead, I would rather hear that than angels singing.

dialogs.original: Dear lady
dialogs.translated: Dear lady

dialogs.original: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,    After the last enchantment you did here,    A ring in chase of you.   So did I abuse    Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you:    Under your hard construction must I sit,    To force that on you, in a shameful cunning    Which you knew none of yours.   What might you think?    Have you not set mine honor at the stake,    And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts    That tyrannous heart can think?   To one of your receiving    Enough is shown.   A cypress, not a bosom,    Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.
dialogs.translated: Please, let me speak. After the magic spell you cast on me last time you were here, I sent that ring to you. With that trick I degraded myself, my servant, and you, I'm afraid. I must then accept your judgment of this act, which you probably condemnfor I forced that ring on you through shameful trickery, and without your consent. What must you think of me? Haven't you tied my honor to a stake like a bear, and let the hounds of your anger attack it? But I've shown my situation clearly enough for someone of your intelligence to understand. My heart's on my sleeveI can't hide my passion. So let me hear you speak.

dialogs.original: I pity you.
dialogs.translated: I pity you.

dialogs.original: Thats a degree to love.
dialogs.translated: That's a step towards love.

dialogs.original: No, not a grize. For tis a vulgar proofThat very oft we pity enemies.
dialogs.translated: No, not a step. It's a common experience that we often pity our enemies.

dialogs.original: Why then methinks tis time to smile again.    O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!    If one should be a prey, how much the better    To fall before the lion than the wolf!
dialogs.translated: Then I think it's time for me to smile again. Oh, how easy it is for the poor to be proud of something they don't have! But if I must be defeated, then better to be defeated by a noble enemy than a lowly one.

dialogs.original: The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.    Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you.    And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,    Your wife is like to reap a proper man.    There lies your way, due west.
dialogs.translated: See, the clock scolds me for wasting time. Don't worry, youth, I won't keep pursuing you. And when you're older and wiser, your future wife will have a fine handsome husband. There's your way back home, due west.

dialogs.original: Then westward ho!Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship!Youll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?
dialogs.translated: Then I'm off to the west! I wish you the best of fortune. You don't have a message for the duke?

dialogs.original: Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.
dialogs.translated: Stay, please, and tell me what you really think of me.

dialogs.original: That you do think you are not what you are.
dialogs.translated: I think that you're not who you think you are.

dialogs.original: If I think so, I think the same of you.
dialogs.translated: If that's true, then I think the same thing of you.

dialogs.original: Then think you right: I am not what I am.
dialogs.translated: Then you're correct. I am not what I seem to be.

dialogs.original: I would you were as I would have you be!
dialogs.translated: I wish you were what I want you to be!

dialogs.original: Would it be better, madam, than I am? I wish it might, for now I am your fool.
dialogs.translated: Would that be better, madam, than me being what I am? I wish that it would, for right now I'm a fool.

dialogs.original: (aside]   Oh, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful    In the contempt and anger of his lip!    A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon    Than love that would seem hid. Loves night is noon.    [To   VIOLA]   Cesario, by the roses of the spring,    By maidhood, honor, truth, and everything,    I love thee so,   that, maugre all thy pride,    Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.    Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,    For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,    But rather reason thus with reason fetter.    Love sought is good, but given unsought better.
dialogs.translated: [To herself] Oh, look how beautiful he is even in his anger and contempt! A murderer's guilt is easier to hide than feelings of love. Midday is like nighttime for lovethat's how brightly passion shines. [To VIOLA] Cesario, I swear by the roses of spring, by virginity, by honor, by truth, and by everything, that I love you. I love you so much that neither my wit nor my reason can hide my passion, despite your pride. Don't draw the wrong conclusions from this, thoughjust because I'm wooing you doesn't mean you shouldn't woo me. Use your better logic and see that love asked for is good, but love freely given is better.

dialogs.original: By innocence I swear, and by my youth    I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,    And that no woman has, nor never none    Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.    And so adieu, good madam. Nevermore    Will I my masters tears to you deplore.
dialogs.translated: And I swear by innocence and by my own youth that I have only one heart and one love to give, and no woman has ever ruled them, and never willexcept for myself. And so I'll say farewell, good madam. I'll never again try to make you pity my master's passion.

dialogs.original: Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.
dialogs.translated: But come again, for you might still convince my heart, which hates him now, to somehow accept his love.
